description: Essential feature is a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior in which the basic rights of others or major age-appropriate societal norms or rules are violated

related_diagnoses.Oppositional Defiant Disorder: Common precursor to the childhood-onset type of conduct disorder
related_diagnoses.Antisocial Personality Disorder: May be considered when symptoms persist into adulthood
related_diagnoses.Substance-Related Disorders: Often an associated feature, particularly in adolescent females
related_diagnoses.Mood Disorders: Increased risk for later in life
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: Increased risk for later in life
related_diagnoses.Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: Increased risk for later in life
related_diagnoses.Impulse-Control Disorders: Increased risk for later in life
related_diagnoses.Psychotic Disorders: Increased risk for later in life
related_diagnoses.Somatic Symptom Disorders: Increased risk for later in life

description: Repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior violating basic rights of others or societal norms

related_diagnoses.Oppositional Defiant Disorder: Less severe disruptive behavior; includes emotional dysregulation
related_diagnoses.Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder: Disruptive behavior but doesn't violate societal norms
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder, Bipolar Disor: Behavioral problems associated with mood disturbances
related_diagnoses.Adjustment Disorders: Develops in response to stressors and resolves after stress ends
related_diagnoses.Antisocial Personality Disorder: Violates basic rights of others or societal norms, often develops from conduct disorder spectrum

description: Deliberate and purposeful fire setting on more than one occasion.
Tension or affective arousal before the act.
Fascination with, interest in, curiosity about, or attraction to fire and its situational contexts.
Pleasure, gratification, or relief when setting fires or when witnessing or participating in their aftermath.
A disorder characterized by recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or monetary value.
Often begins in adolescence but can start in childhood, adulthood, or even late adulthood.

related_diagnoses.ordinary theft: Distinguished from ordinary acts of theft based on motivation and intent.
related_diagnoses.malingering: May simulate symptoms to avoid criminal prosecution.
related_diagnoses.antisocial personality disorder and cond: General pattern of antisocial behavior differentiates it.
related_diagnoses.manic episodes, psychotic episodes, and: Intentional or inadvertent stealing during these states distinguishes them.

description: A cluster of cognitive, behavioral, and physiological symptoms indicating continued substance use despite significant problems.

related_diagnoses.Tolerance: Signaled by needing a higher dose for desired effect or reduced effect with usual dose.
related_diagnoses.Withdrawal: Syndrome occurring when blood or tissue concentrations of a substance decline in an individual who had maintained prolonged heavy use.

description: A reversible substance-specific syndrome due to recent ingestion.
Clinically significant problematic behavioral or psychological changes attributed to the physiological effects of the substance.

related_diagnoses.Withdrawal: Symptoms initiated by a decline in blood or tissue concentrations of a substance.

description: Potentially severe, temporary, but sometimes persisting central nervous system (CNS) syndromes developing due to substance abuse, medications, or toxins.
Distinguishable from substance use disorders

related_diagnoses.Delirium: Symptoms may be observed during delirium, so diagnosis should be based on delirium rather than separately diagnosing the psychiatric syndrome.

duration: usually temporary, likely to disappear within 1 month
description: mental disorders developing due to intoxication or withdrawal from substances of abuse or prescribed/over-the-counter medications.
similar symptom profiles to independent mental disorders but tend to resolve upon cessation of substance/medication.

related_diagnoses.independent mental disorders: can have identical symptoms but different treatments and prognoses
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: often combined diagnosis in ICD-10-CM coding

description: A cluster of behavioral and physical symptoms including withdrawal, tolerance, and craving.
Repetitive and intense use leading to devoting significant time to obtain and consume alcohol.

related_diagnoses.conduct disorder: often co-occurs with alcohol- and other substance-related disorders

description: Condition characterized by problematic pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress

related_diagnoses.impulsivity: Associated with enhanced rates of all substance use disorders and gambling disorder

symptoms: Increased risk of accidents, violence, and suicide
description: Major areas of life functioning likely to be impaired due to heavy alcohol consumption.
Repeated and significant distress or impaired functioning caused by heavy alcohol doses.

related_diagnoses.Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Di: Must be distinguished due to differing courses, especially concerning medical problems.
related_diagnoses.Antisocial Personality Disorder: Worsens prognosis and increases risk of alcohol use disorder.
related_diagnoses.Bipolar Disorders, Schizophrenia, Antiso: Markedly increased rates of Alcohol Use Disorder.
related_diagnoses.Depression: Temporary, alcohol-induced comorbid depressive symptoms possible.

symptoms: Transient visual, tactile, or auditory hallucinations or illusions
description: Characteristic withdrawal syndrome developing within several hours to a few days after the cessation of (or reduction in) heavy and prolonged alcohol use.
Causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

related_diagnoses.Substance Use Disorder: Can only occur in the presence of a moderate or severe alcohol use disorder.
related_diagnoses.Delirium Tremens: May occur in the context of withdrawal.
related_diagnoses.Seizures: Less than 3% of individuals experience withdrawal seizures.

symptoms: Rambling flow of thought and speech
description: Recent consumption of caffeine leading to specified symptoms

related_diagnoses.Caffeine Withdrawal: Opposite effects upon discontinuation of regular caffeine use.

symptoms: rambling flow of thought and speech
sensory disturbances (ringing in the ears and flashes of light)
description: Recent consumption of caffeine leading to five or more signs or symptoms developing during or shortly after caffeine use.
Symptoms causing clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

related_diagnoses.Caffeine Withdrawal: Abrupt cessation of or reduction in caffeine use resulting in a characteristic withdrawal syndrome.

symptoms: Increased theta power and decreased beta-2 power electroencephalographically
duration: Lasts for 2-9 days, with the possibility of withdrawal headaches occurring for up to 21 days.
description: Abrupt cessation of caffeine intake leads to various physical and mental symptoms.

symptoms: Giving up important activities due to cannabis use
Using cannabis in physically hazardous situations
Continuing cannabis use despite knowing about persisting or recurring problems linked to it
Experiencing withdrawal symptoms upon stopping cannabis use
Strong craving or urge to use cannabis
description: A disorder characterized by problematic patterns of cannabis use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress

related_diagnoses.Comorbid Alcohol Use Disorder: Often co-occurs with alcohol abuse or dependence.
related_diagnoses.Cocaine Use Disorder: Frequently seen alongside cocaine abuse or dependence.

symptoms: exaggerated craving and impulse for specific foods
spending an excessive amount of time under the influence or recovering from its effects
continuing use despite clear risks of negative consequences
reports of cannabis use exacerbating mood, sleep, pain, or other psychological problems
description: substance use disorder characterized by continued use despite adverse consequences

related_diagnoses.conduct disorder: early onset linked to higher risk of cannabis use disorder
related_diagnoses.antisocial personality disorder: risk factor for substance-related disorders including cannabis-related disorders

description: Chronic intake of cannabis can lead to a lack of motivation resembling persistent depressive disorder.
Can cause or exacerbate various mental disorders, particularly schizophrenia.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: can exacerbate symptoms or contribute to its onset
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: commonly observed alongside cannabis use disorder
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: frequently co-occur with cannabis use disorder
related_diagnoses.Conduct Disorder: common in adolescents with cannabis use disorder
related_diagnoses.Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder: common in adolescents with cannabis use disorder
related_diagnoses.Substance Use Disorders (alcohol, cocain: highly comorbid with cannabis use disorder

symptoms: euphoria with inappropriate laughter and grandiosity
difficulty carrying out complex mental processes
sensation that time is passing slowly
occasionally anxiety, dysphoria, or social withdrawal
hallucinations (without intact reality testing - leading to consideration of substance/medication-induced psychotic disorder)
duration: effects usually last 3-4 hours; occasional persistence or recurrence for 12-24 hours due to slow release of psychoactive substances from fatty tissue or enterohepatic circulation.
description: presence of clinically significant problematic behavioral or psychological changes developing during or shortly after cannabis use

related_diagnoses.substance/medication-induced psychotic d: if hallucinations occur in the absence of intact reality testing
related_diagnoses.alcohol intoxication: decreases appetite, increases aggressive behavior, produces nystagmus or ataxia (differentiates)
related_diagnoses.sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic intoxi: decreases appetite, increases aggressive behavior, produces nystagmus or ataxia (differentiates)
related_diagnoses.phencyclidine intoxication: causes perceptual changes, ataxia, and aggressive behavior (differentiates)
related_diagnoses.cannabis-induced anxiety disorder: distinguishes from cannabis intoxication based on predominant symptoms and severity requiring separate clinical attention
related_diagnoses.cannabis withdrawal: develops after cessation of heavy and prolonged cannabis use, characterized by irritability, nervousness/anxiety, sleep difficulties, decreased appetite/weight loss, restlessness, depressed mood, and physical symptoms causing significant discomfort.

description: Pattern of phencyclidine (or similar substance) use causing impairment or distress.
Symptoms including tolerance, craving, inability to control usage, etc.

related_diagnoses.Comorbid Phencyclidine-Induced Psychosis: May lead to psychosis resembling Schizophrenia
related_diagnoses.Coexisting Alcohol/Tobacco Withdrawal: Can mimic symptoms of other substance withdrawals

description: Disorder characterized by problematic pattern of hallucinogen use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Some effects may resemble low mood.
related_diagnoses.Conduct Disorder/Antisocial Personality: Violent aggressive behaviors may be similar.

description: A diverse group of substances producing similar alterations of perception, mood, and cognition.
Includes phenylalkylamines, indoleamines, ergolines, and others.

related_diagnoses.Substance-Related and Addictive Disorder: May include other substance use disorders, particularly alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis.

duration: Several minutes to several hours or longer depending on the specific hallucinogen.
description: Clinically significant problematic behavioral or psychological changes that develop during or shortly after hallucinogen use.

related_diagnoses.Substance Intoxication: To differentiate from intoxication due to other substances.
related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Considered when there is no intact reality testing.
related_diagnoses.Sepsis: Listed as a consideration in differential diagnosis.
